Ben Hood.Action: Checks in on Paul, shows concern for his plans and well-being.
Encourages Wendy to talk to Paul on the phone despite her initial reluctance.
Defends the president when Wendy disparages him.
Checks in on his son Paul, confirms travel plans, and tries to encourage family connection by involving Wendy in the phone call.
Interrupts the phone call to make Wendy say hi to Paul, demonstrating some awkwardness in managing family dynamics.
Reacts with mild reprimand to Wendy's disrespectful comment about Nixon, showing some adherence to respect but possibly lacking emotional intelligence in handling children's outbursts.
Retreats to the wet bar to pour another drink after overhearing a tense argument, then decides not to pour more on Elena's refusal.
Accurately predicts Billy Jack movie's success, advises investors on entertainment stocks.
Reacting awkwardly when wine is spilled on him, slightly stumbling over words.
Teases Wendy about cooking and criticizes Jim, but lightly and familiarly.
Gently pulls on the telephone cord to check if Wendy is still awake.
Firmly tells Wendy to go to sleep but uses a lighthearted 'fascist' joke.
Enters Wendy's room angrily but softens his tone, caresses the blanket where her cheek is, showing tenderness.
Has a warm, gentle goodnight exchange with Wendy, calling her 'kiddo.'
Observes Elena with a pause and attention after coming out of the bathroom, suggesting quiet care or concern.
Pauses and looks at Elena thoughtfully before speaking, showing attentiveness.
Responds skeptically but listens to Elena’s concerns about Wendy, indicating some concern.
Expresses frustration about discussing problems rather than avoiding them, showing a desire for open communication.
Does not escalate the argument despite Elena's harsh words, demonstrating restraint and respect.
Leaves the room quietly, pauses wistfully at the door, then says good night, indicating emotional conflict and a gentle demeanor.
Uses sarcasm and dismissive language about therapy and their issues, which may inhibit sincere emotional connection.
Avoids directly engaging with Elena’s emotional request for him to attend to Wendy or deal with family matters seriously.
Engages in a candid conversation with Elena about family issues, shows some self-awareness and willingness to listen.
Avoids making a decision to move out or resolve family issues, described as possibly lazy or scared.
Responds to confrontation calmly and respectfully, leaves the room without escalating the conflict.
Offers to have George cover the old filmed entertainment sector, showing trust in his abilities.
Makes a sarcastic comment ('Up the organization! ... Bastard.') under his breath after George leaves, indicating frustration but no direct hostility.
Suggests not always having to go to his father's club for lunch, implying some attempt at considering others' perspectives.
Attempts to engage his father in a serious conversation seeking advice about his marriage.
Shows some hesitancy and difficulty in expressing his feelings clearly, indicating vulnerability.
Does not react antagonistically to his father's dismissive and harsh comments, remains relatively calm.
Attempts to seek advice from his father about personal matters, showing willingness to engage and reflect.
Struggles to clearly communicate his situation, trailing off and avoiding direct discussion.
Confronts his father's outdated and unsupportive views rather than passively accepting them.
Fails to assert himself decisively in the conversation, allowing his father to dominate the interaction.
Admits uncertainty about his feelings, shows vulnerability by saying 'maybe I love her'
Does not stand up to his father's harshness or take control of the conversation, appearing passive
Corrects his father about the year, showing attentiveness but hesitates and shows indecision about his feelings towards Elena.
Ponders his feelings and expresses uncertainty and weakness when talking about love, indicating lack of confidence and decisiveness.
Admits insecurity and frustration about golf and being humiliated by a colleague.
Responds to Janey's gentle rejection of his conversational attempt with irony and sarcasm about having an affair.
Acknowledges Janey's point and ends the interaction without further pushing.
Acknowledges his declining golf skills humorously and self-reflectively, showing awareness of his own competence.
Continues babbling about golf and coworker George Clair's improvement in an insecure, somewhat defeated tone, revealing lack of confidence.
Responds quickly and wittily to Janey's rebuke, showing social awareness and verbal agility.
Leaves quietly and cautiously, indicating some social or situational awkwardness or lack of assertiveness.
Applauds Wendy's trombone playing and encourages her music involvement.
Makes a vague comment 'Can't wait to see how it fits in with all the other instruments,' possibly not fully engaged or insightful about Wendy's music skills.
Leans over and kisses Elena on the cheek before going to bed.
Responds uncertainly when Elena asks about his new aftershave, recoiling slightly.
Replies briefly and avoids engaging deeply about going to the Halfords' event, deciding to go to bed early.
Fills a glass with ice and initiates a casual conversation about the neighborhood tradition, showing awareness and social consideration.
Acts uncertainly when walking out of the room after a conversation with Elena, recoiling slightly when asked about aftershave, suggesting discomfort or lack of confidence.
Decides not to argue further with his father about the house sale, showing restraint.
Mentions Thanksgiving plans and inquires about his father's attendance, showing some family consideration.
Spits out his drink in shock at his father's crude joke about his nurse.
Acknowledges his father's actions regarding the house sale and IRS issues, attempts to engage in a serious conversation.
Recognizes the joke by his father and questions it, showing awareness.
Decides not to pursue an overworked topic, showing restraint in conversation.
No actions or statements present in the excerpt to evaluate competence.
Works cooperatively with Elena to free the frozen turkey from the freezer, sharing a smile after their joint effort.
Notices Elena's vaguely distraught look and gently inquires if she is all right.
Works with Elena to extract the frozen turkey from the freezer, asks for help appropriately.
Forgets or is unsure about picking up the cranberry sauce, showing some forgetfulness.
Gently makes light of Elena's sadness, attempts to engage in communication despite awkwardness.
Responds defensively when Elena brings up concerns about their relationship and communication.
Abruptly leaves the conversation to attend to obligation, cutting off further communication.
Offers to wash Elena's shirt for her, looks ruefully when declined.
Greets Mikey warmly and asks about his business.
Invites Wendy to come with him to pick up Paul.
Engages Paul in conversation, shows interest in his school life and well-being.
Invites daughter Wendy to come along to pick up Paul but accepts her refusal without pressing; engages politely with son Paul about school and life, showing supportive and composed behavior.
Smells the armpits of the shirt he is putting on and reacts with a negative comment, showing awareness of his personal hygiene albeit in a somewhat awkward manner.
Fiddles for his car keys while responding to Mikey's awkwardness, appearing somewhat uneasy and tense rather than confident or skillful in social interaction.
Initiates a talk with his son Paul about sensitive topics, trying to offer fatherly advice in a casual, humorous manner.
Runs a stop sign while distracted during the conversation, showing some carelessness.
Asks Paul to pretend the awkward conversation never happened, showing some self-awareness and concern for son's comfort.
Attempts to have a serious father-son talk about sexuality, showing some initiative and concern.
Delivers awkward and somewhat misguided advice on self-abuse; shows lack of social tact and awareness.
Runs a stop sign and almost causes an accident, indicating poor attention and careless behavior.
Acknowledges his awkwardness and asks his son to forget his strange comments, demonstrating some self-awareness.
Smirks at Paul smoking in the bathroom and makes a teasing comment ('Sure you will.')
Starts the Thanksgiving meal by acknowledging family unity ('Well, it's great we can all be together....')
Prepares the Thanksgiving turkey, indicating he is taking responsibility for an important task.
Attempts to use the bathroom but is locked out, then returns with a smirk at Paul's behavior, showing awareness and a confident, relaxed attitude.
Initiates the Thanksgiving meal with a comment but the family remains silent and unmoving, possibly showing a lack of ability to manage or ease family tension.
Attempts to keep Thanksgiving calm and together despite family tension.
Interrupts Wendy to stop her controversial grace, showing discomfort with her cynicism.
Shares a moment of intimacy with Janey and expresses concern about Elena suspecting something.
Dismisses the potential emotional issues in his marriage by deflecting responsibility onto observing his wife rather than addressing problems directly.
Watches Janey leave without confronting her or trying to stop her, then drinks alone and wanders the house.
Idly goes through Janey's personal drawers and belongings, including rifling through medicines and picking up a garter belt.
Carefully opens the door and looks for Janey after hearing noises. Tries to see what is happening instead of ignoring it.
Fails to stop Janey from leaving or communicate with her before she drives away.
Drinks vodka while alone, wanders the house aimlessly, and idly goes through Janey's drawers and things.
Comically interacts with the water bed, showing some lightheartedness and awareness of surroundings.
Interrupts Wendy and Mikey's semi-sexual play by appearing suddenly in the basement, silently observing, causing them to immediately stop and cover up.
Overhears teenagers secretly engaging in inappropriate behavior and confronts them by appearing above them at the stairs, effectively stopping the situation.
Confronts Wendy and Mikey about their behavior with suspicion and harsh language.
Takes Wendy's arm while walking and tries to reassure her, showing concern.
Expresses doubt about Wendy's boyfriend's seriousness and future, implying protection and care.
Asks Wendy if her toes are cold during their walk in the rain, indicating attention to her comfort.
He stops and lifts Wendy in his arms, offering to carry her up the drive, creating a moment of intimacy.
Tells Wendy to go dry off when they enter the house, showing care about her comfort.
Shares a story about finding Wendy in the basement with Mikey, expressing concern and scolding Mikey for inappropriate behavior.
Engages in casual, somewhat nervous conversation with Elena, complimenting her appearance.
Downplays the reason for being in the basement (dropping off a coffee cup), revealing somewhat evasive behavior.
Carries Wendy in his arms to help her get out of the cold and wet, showing care and decisiveness.
Confronts the situation with Mikey decisively by scolding him, indicating protective instincts and assertiveness.
Explains his presence in the Williams' basement with a plausible excuse, handling potential suspicion calmly and smoothly.
Acts nervously while recounting the confrontation, showing slight unease or lack of complete confidence.
Says 'Stay out of trouble' to Paul before he leaves.
Asks about Paul's date with a Park Avenue address in a teasing manner ('What's the name of this girl? Libbets? What kind of name is Libbets?').
Fishes his dropped plate out of the trash and sets it on the counter.
Attempts to engage Elena in conversation about her mood, despite her resistance and vague responses.
Acknowledges feelings of loneliness and admits he is not having fun with the situation.
Responds defensively to Elena's confrontation, deflecting responsibility and insulting her perspective.

Engages in a tense conversation with Elena where he questions the nature of faithfulness but does not openly admit fault; tries to rationalize situation using 'hard facts' and external references rather than direct emotional engagement.

Attempts to maintain control of the conversation by responding calmly and quietly to accusations, showing some self-awareness ('I'm not having any fun at it'), but avoids addressing core issues honestly and transparently.

Does not effectively resolve or address marital conflict; shows avoidance, defensiveness, and rationalization rather than taking responsibility or showing emotional intelligence in a difficult situation.
Silently joins Elena in going to a social gathering despite apparent tiredness and unspoken mood.
Lack of verbal communication with Elena during the car ride, suggesting emotional distance or withdrawal.
Seemingly tired, stands silently before Elena when confronted; does not engage in meaningful conversation or explanation.
Gets ready and leaves the house with Elena despite the foreboding weather, prepared for the social event.
Maintains silence and does not speak with Elena in the car during the drive to the party, showing lack of communication or initiative.
Expresses reluctance to stay at the key party and reassures Elena that he is not there to cheat, emphasizing neighborly respect.
Tries to calm Elena down and insists there is no hidden plot or ill intent.
Suggests putting in an appearance briefly and leaving to avoid staying at a problematic party, demonstrating awareness and practical thinking.
Fails to prevent misunderstanding with Elena about the key party, appears somewhat unaware of the social dynamics and suspicions around him.
Admits to feeling bad about having done something he didn't want to do.
Dismisses Elena's feelings by telling her she's 'just getting wound up to get wound up.'
Immediately pours himself a stiff drink upon entering a social gathering, seeming to avoid engaging meaningfully with others initially.
Greets George Clair warmly and engages in friendly, casual conversation.
Makes straight for Janey and confronts her about waiting for him in boxer shorts, expressing frustration and demanding an explanation.
Offers a quick, confident judgment about the sequel to The Godfather, predicting it will fail and backing it with reasons about public taste.
Makes a direct, confrontational approach to Janey, demanding explanations for her earlier absence in a somewhat loud whisper that risks embarrassment.
Declines the joint initially, showing some self-restraint.
Accepts the joint after some consideration and reacts positively.
Appears uncomfortable and somewhat awkward in a tense social exchange with Janey, unable to respond kindly or calmly.
Watches Janey wander off instead of trying to resolve the conflict, showing some social withdrawal or avoidance.
Decides to do chores before the party, showing some planning and follow-through.
Confused and uncertain about Janey's revelation regarding Jimmy, reacts emotionally and stalls.
Initially refuses a joint but then decides to try it; shows some poor judgment by smoking and immediately coughing.
Attempts to engage in conversation and listens to others' opinions (Jack Moellering), indicating some intellectual curiosity.
Responds to Boland's crude joke with distaste, indicating awareness and social sensitivity.
Is at the bar pouring another drink, engaging in drinking despite underlying social awkwardness.
Allows Elena to care for him when he's woozy, accepts her concern quietly and gratefully.
Insists on driving while intoxicated before being persuaded otherwise.
Insists on driving despite being unfit, but ultimately accepts Elena's insistence that he should not drive and agrees to sleep it off.
Drives slowly and carefully, observes surroundings, stops when noticing something on icy embankment.
Drives slowly and cautiously, notices something unusual, and stops the car to investigate.
Leans down, turns Mike's body over, shows amazement and saddened shock.
Picks up Mike's body and carries him over the hill and onto the street despite great effort.
Leans down and turns Mike's body over, then carries him over the hill and onto the street despite the enormous physical effort and falling several times but getting back up.
Lays Mikey's body down carefully, shows concern about calling for help, tries to help despite the tense situation.
Attempts to intervene despite the unwelcoming atmosphere from the Williams family.
Is breathless and shaken, indicates emotional strain but remains present at the scene.
Lays Mikey's body down gently and attempts to communicate with others despite being breathless; tries to suggest calling someone despite the phone being out.
Appears overwhelmed and unable to fully lead or take control of the crisis situation; relies on others' input and fails to decisively act beyond basic responses.
Joins Elena and Wendy calmly to leave the scene, showing presence of mind to remove themselves when not wanted.
Turns off the engine and quietly begins to cry, indicating emotional openness and vulnerability in front of his family.
Attempts to tell his children something important, showing willingness to communicate and share with family.
His wife Elena reaches out to comfort him, although not fully touching, signaling a moment of family tenderness and connection involving Ben.
Starts the car confidently, attempting to drive off despite difficult light conditions.
Turns off the engine upon being blinded by sunlight, showing awareness and caution.
Begins to cry quietly before addressing his children, indicating emotional vulnerability which may impact his capacity to remain composed and decisive in moment of family crisis.
Attempts to communicate an important message to his children but is interrupted and unable to complete it, suggesting difficulty in managing delicate conversations under stress.
